Award.AwardTitle: Supporting a Community Building Workshop in Computer Education Research

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
To improve our understanding of the state of computing education and to grow the field, the Partnership for Advancing Computing Education (PACE) proposes to organize an interdisciplinary planning workshop on computing education research. PACE, a coalition of the ACM, the Association of Information Systems, IEEE-Computer Society, Computer Science Teachers Association, the Computing Research Association, and the National Center for Women & IT, is dedicated to improving the preparation of the computing workforce. Through discussion among leading computing and education researchers, we propose to achieve the following goals:
(i) to develop a shared understanding of the state of computing education research across subdisciplines
of computing, identifying gaps and overlaps;
(ii) to identify present strengths and future opportunities for research on computing education;
(iii) to assess the viability of building mechanisms for improved infrastructure, such as a research coordination network, and
(iv) to encourage knowledge sharing across the fragmented domains of study.

POR.DRECONTENT:
To deliver excellence in computing education commensurate with society’s need for a skilled and multidisciplinary computing workforce, educators need to identify, adopt, and adapt—and often discover—pedagogical best practices. In most of the computing subdisciplines (namely, in alphabetical order, computer engineering, computer science, information systems, information technology and software engineering), Computing Education Research (CER) is an important area of research, and many individual researchers and research programs have made significant progress. In many cases solutions tend to, however, be more anecdotal than systematic. Generally speaking, the computing subdisciplines conduct CER in isolation from each other. Useful information and research results reside in silos accessible only to scholars within that particular subdiscipline or to members of the professional organization sponsoring the research. Users of CER rarely seek to borrow from or share information with colleagues in other subdisciplines or related disciplines and often end up “reinventing the wheel,” expending effort and resources to ask questions an educator has already addressed.

Not surprisingly, all of the participants of the Partnership for Advancing Computing Education (PACE) workshop on CER perceived education research as very important but also recognized that this research is often conducted haphazardly and rarely shared across disciplines. Compounding this fragmentation and isolation is the relatively low status of much CER as perceived by those granting promotion and tenure. Although academic research is a vital part of most computing disciplines, research focused on improving pedagogy is generally undervalued and ill rewarded in the university system. Further, the CER community does not seem to be growing and developing as perceived, for instance, by attendances at conferences (such as the International Computing Education Research Conference) and by the manner in which it was responding to funding initiatives (e.g., from the US National Science Foundation).

The subdisciplines of computing share many goals and research areas. Teaching methods and resources developed for use by students in one subdiscipline might be easily adapted to enhance the educational experience of students in a related field. Professional computing organizations, some with a very significant reach, have commitments to the entry-level and ongoing education of their members. They are properly motivated and well positioned to help disseminate teaching methods among computing sub-disciplines and computing-intensive fields.

This workshop, organized under the auspices of PACE, sought to draw these issues to the attention of the community and start to chart a way ahead that would result in a healthier and more vibrant computing education research community. Seeking input from education research in other allied disciplines was seen as offering fruitful insights.

The workshop outcome recommends specific actions to address these broad challenges. These issues and concerns are also common in allied computing-intensive disciplines and in many aspects of education generally include:

  • Broaden participation by women, minorities, and students who are first in their families to attend college, and related cultural issues;

  • Understand how learning occurs and how learning can be measured;

  • Understand when interventions are desirable, which interventions work in particular

    situations, and how and when it is best to deliver them;
